description: 1533, "to turn over in the mind," also "to chew cud" (1547), from Latin rūminātus, past participle of rūmināre (“to chew the cud, turn over in the mind”), from rūmen (“the throat, gullet”), of uncertain origin.

entries.meaning: (botany) Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filled with softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North American papaw.

verbs.description: ruminate (third-person singular simple present ruminates, present participle ruminating, simple past and past participle ruminated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To chew cud. (Said of ruminants.) Involves regurgitating partially digested food from the rumen.
examples: A camel will ruminate just as a cow will.
I didn't answer right away because I needed to ruminate first.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To meditate or ponder over; to muse on.
examples: Mad with desire, she ruminates her sin.
